contentrichtext.text: {{no footnotes|date=March 2013}} The current '''capital of Wales''' is [[Cardiff]], which was first referred to as such in 1955, when [[Gwilym Lloyd George, 1st Viscount Tenby|Gwilym Lloyd-George]], then Minister for Welsh Affairs commented in a Parliamentary written answer that "no formal measures are necessary to give effect to this decision". Since 1999, Cardiff has been the location of the [[National Assembly for Wales]]. In the past, other places have been regarded as the Welsh capital, including *[[Strata Florida]], the [[Cistercian]] [[abbey]] where [[Llywelyn the Great]] held council in 1238. *[[Machynlleth]], where [[Owain GlyndÅµr]] held a parliament in 1404. *[[Ludlow]], England, seat of the [[Council of Wales and the Marches]] from 1473 to 1689. The [[ecclesiastical]] capital of Wales is [[St David's]], the birthplace of the country's patron saint, [[Saint David|David]]. The [[National Library of Wales]] is located in none of these, instead being sited in [[Aberystwyth]]. ==External links== *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/2854567.stm BBC News: Capital claims - A city's struggle] [[Category:British capitals]] [[Category:Politics of Wales]] [[Category:1955 introductions]] {{Wales-stub}}
